unnormalised: A minor fire broke out at the Medicity Hospital in Gurgaon earlier today, causing a temporary disruption of services and a frantic evacuation of patients. According to initial reports, the fire, suspected to be caused by a short circuit, started in the records room on the 2nd floor, where vast amounts of patient data are stored, including sensitive identifiers like UHIDs (Unique Health Identifiers) and insurance policy numbers. Fortunately, no casualties were reported, thanks to the swift action of the hospital staff and the Gurgaon fire department.
normalised: A minor fire broke out at the Medicity Hospital in Gurgaon earlier today, causing a temporary disruption of services and a frantic evacuation of patients. According to initial reports, the fire, suspected to be caused by a short circuit, started in the records room on the second floor, where vast amounts of patient data are stored, including sensitive identifiers like U-H-I-Ds (Unique Health Identifiers) and insurance policy numbers. Fortunately, no casualties were reported, thanks to the swift action of the hospital staff and the Gurgaon fire department.

unnormalised: Amongst the evacuated patients was Mrs. Sunita Devi, admitted with a pre-existing heart condition. Speaking from outside the hospital, wrapped in a shawl, she recounted her ordeal, "It was so sudden. One moment I was resting, and the next, the nurses were rushing us out, shouting about a fire. I only had time to grab my purse; my medical file is still inside, with my Arogya Sanjeevani policy details – the policy number is ASL/2023/1234567." She expressed concern about potential delays in her treatment due to the disruption.

unnormalised: Another patient, Mr. Rajesh Kumar, who was visiting his ailing mother, voiced similar concerns. "My mother is undergoing treatment for pneumonia. Her insurance details – a Star Health policy with ID STAR/HLTH/2022/9876543 – are crucial for processing the bills. I hope the fire didn't damage those records," he stated, visibly worried. Hospital sources confirmed that backup servers containing digitized patient data, including UHIDs formatted as MHID2024-ABC-123, remained unaffected and were stored offsite.

unnormalised: The hospital administration, led by Dr. Malhotra, issued a statement emphasizing their commitment to patient safety and data security. “We deeply regret the inconvenience caused by this unfortunate incident. We are working diligently to restore normal operations and retrieve any physical records that may have been affected. Patients needing their policy numbers – like Bajaj Allianz policy number BA/HLTH/23/5678901 or their government-issued Ayushman Bharat ID AB-1234-5678-9012 – can contact our helpline for assistance. A dedicated team is being set up to manage the recovery and to address patient queries and concerns about their medical records”, he assured.

unnormalised: However, the incident has raised concerns about the safety and security of patient data, particularly with the increasing reliance on digitized medical records. Experts are emphasizing the need for stringent fire safety measures in healthcare facilities, coupled with robust data backup and recovery systems. Cyber security experts are also cautioning on the need for hospitals to have robust security measures for protection of sensitive data in the electronic form, like the UHIDs of patients, insurance IDs and other sensitive details.

unnormalised: The Gurgaon fire department is conducting a thorough investigation to determine the exact cause of the fire and to assess the extent of the damage. An internal audit is also being conducted by Medicity Hospital to determine the efficacy of their fire safety measures and data protection protocols. Authorities have promised that they will be providing updates to the public about the situation, and ensure all medical facilities in the area have adequate preparedness to deal with similar disasters in the future.

As the cleanup efforts continue and the hospital works to restore normalcy, patients and their families remain apprehensive, hoping for a swift resolution and minimal disruption to their ongoing medical care.
